claim: Twins are always born during the same year.

supporting.text: Twins are born from the same pregnancy, which typically lasts less than one year, ensuring they share the same birth year.

attacks.text: Twins are born from the same pregnancy, which typically lasts less than one year, ensuring they share the same birth year.
In rare cases, twins can be born on either side of midnight on New Year's Eve, resulting in different birth years.
The probability of twins being born on different sides of midnight on New Year's Eve is astronomically low, making A1's argument practically valid for almost all cases.
Twins can also be born in different years if the pregnancy spans a leap second adjustment, though this is extremely rare.

supporting.text: Medical records and birth certificates document twins as being born on the same day or within minutes/hours of each other, never crossing a year boundary.

attacks.text: Medical records and birth certificates document twins as being born on the same day or within minutes/hours of each other, never crossing a year boundary.
In extremely rare cases, twins can be born on either side of midnight on New Year's Eve, resulting in different birth years.
The occurrence of twins born across a year boundary is statistically negligible and does not meaningfully challenge the general rule.

supporting.text: Biological processes of human gestation do not allow for a twin birth to span multiple calendar years, as pregnancies last approximately 9 months.

attacks.text: Biological processes of human gestation do not allow for a twin birth to span multiple calendar years, as pregnancies last approximately 9 months.
In rare cases, twins can be born on either side of midnight on New Year's Eve, resulting in different birth years.
The likelihood of twins being born exactly at midnight is astronomically low, making this exception statistically negligible.
Time zone differences during international travel could theoretically result in twins being born in different years if the mother crosses time zones during labor.
Medical protocols strongly discourage air travel in late-stage pregnancy, making this scenario virtually impossible in practice.

supporting.text: No documented cases exist of twins being born in different years, as childbirth occurs in a single continuous event for twins.

attacks.text: No documented cases exist of twins being born in different years, as childbirth occurs in a single continuous event for twins.
Twins can be born in different years if the birth occurs around midnight on New Year's Eve, with one twin born before midnight and the other after.
Such cases are extremely rare and often require precise timing, making them statistically negligible in general discussions about twin births.
Even rare cases are valid counterexamples, and the original claim uses 'always,' which is absolute and disproven by any exception.
